column69:
Cash and cash equivalents
Cash and cash equivalents comprise "Cash at bank and in hand" and "Current asset investments" as well as âOther short-term debtâ under credit institutions.
column75: The Board of Directors and the Executive Board have today considered and adopted the Annual Report of JYSK Holding A/S for the financial year 1 September 2015 â 31 August 2016.
column76:
Report on the Consolidated Financial Statements and Parent Company Financial Statements
We have audited the Consolidated Financial Statements and the Parent Company Financial Statements of JYSK Holding A/S for the financial year 1 September 2015 - 31 August 2016, which comprise income statement, balance sheet, notes and accounting policies for both the Group and the Parent Company, as well as consolidated cash flow statement. The Consolidated Financial Statements and the Parent Company Financial Statements are prepared in accordance with the Danish Financial Statements Act.
column77: Independent Auditorâs Report
column78: The ratios have been prepared in accordance with the definitions provided under accounting policies.
column79:
Basis of consolidation
The Consolidated Financial Statements comprise the Parent Company, JYSK Holding A/S, and subsidiaries in which the Parent Company directly or indirectly holds more than 50% of the votes or in which the Parent Company, through share ownership or otherwise, exercises control. Enterprises in which the Group holds between 20% and 50% of the votes and exercises significant influence but not control are classified as associates.
Elimination is made of intercompany income and expenses, shareholdings, dividends and accounts as well as of realised and unrealised profits and losses on transactions between the consolidated enterprises.
The financial statements applied for the Groupâs Annual Report have been prepared in accordance with the accounting policies of the Group.
column80:
Non-controlling interests
On statement of group results and group equity, the shares of results and equity of subsidiaries attributable to minority interests are recognised as separate items in the income statement and the balance sheet.
column81: However, a few reclassifications of comparative figures have been made.
column82: The Annual Report of JYSK Holding A/S for the financial year 1 September 2015 to 31 August 2016 has been prepared in accordance with the provisions of the Danish Financial Statements Act applying to large enterprises of reporting class C.
column83:
Segment reporting
In accordance with section 96(1) of the Danish Financial Statements Act, disclosures on revenue broken down by business segments are not provided as the Companyâs Executive Board and Board of Directors assess that such disclosures would be very detrimental to the Company.
column85:
Managementâs Review
Main activity
The activity of the Parent Company comprises operation of real property, investments in subsidiaries and associates as well as current asset investments.
The Groupâs main activities are carried out in subsidiaries dealing in retail trade through the retail chain JYSK selling everything for the bed room, bath room, other rooms, the window and the patio. The activities take place in retail stores in Denmark, Sweden, Norway, Finland, Poland, the Czech Republic, Austria, Hungary, Switzerland, Slovakia, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia, Serbia, the Ukraine, Rumania, Bulgaria and the USA.
Development in the financial year
Group revenue amounts to DKK 15,052,474k compared to DKK 14,072,238k in financial year 2015/16.
Profit before financial income and expenses amounts to DKK 1,100,980k compared to DKK 1,069,902k in 2014/15.
Profit for the year after tax amounts to DKK 1,550,238k compared to DKK 1,407,888k in 2014/15. The result is satisfying and in conjunction with management expectations.
Special risks
The Groupâs activities abroad imply that profit, cash flows and equity are affected by the development in exchange and interest rates of a number of currencies.
Knowledge resources
JYSK develops competent employees to undertake operational and management tasks in the Groupâs retail stores through specially adapted training programmes and at its own academy.
Corporate social responsibility
The statutory statement of corporate social responsibility and statement on the underrepresented gender appear on pages 29 - 39.
Expected development
For the year ahead, JYSK Holding A/S expects to realise a profit in line with the 2015/16 level provided that the financial markets evolve normally.
Subsequent events
No events materially affecting the assessment of the Annual Report have occurred after the balance sheet date.
column86: In our opinion, Managementâs Review includes a true and fair account of the matters addressed in the Review.
column95:
Opinion
In our opinion, the Consolidated Financial Statements and the Parent Company Financial Statements give a true and fair view of the financial position of the Group and the Company at 31 August 2015 and of the results of the Group and Parent Company operations as well as the consolidated cash flows for the financial year 1 September 2015 - 31 August 2016 in accordance with the Danish Financial Statements Act.
column99: We recommend that the Annual Report be adopted at the Annual General Meeting.
column105: Managementâs Statement
column106:
Auditorâs Responsibility
Our responsibility is to express an opinion on the Consolidated Financial Statements and the Parent Company Financial Statements based on our audit. We conducted our audit in accordance with International Standards on Auditing and additional requirements in accordance with Danish audit regulation. This requires that we comply with ethical requirements and plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance whether the Consolidated Financial Statements and the Parent Company Financial Statements are free from material misstatement.
An audit involves performing audit procedures to obtain audit evidence about the amounts and disclosures in the Consolidated Financial Statements and the Parent Company Financial Statements. The audit procedures selected depend on the auditorâs judgment, including the assessment of the risks of material misstatement of the Consolidated Financial Statements and the Parent Company Financial Statements, whether due to fraud or error. In making those risk assessments, the auditor considers internal control relevant to the Companyâs preparation of Consolidated Financial Statements and Parent Company Financial Statements that give a true and fair view in order to design audit procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing an opinion on the effectiveness of the Companyâs internal control. An audit also includes evaluating the appropriateness of accounting policies used and the reasonableness of accounting estimates made by Management, as well as evaluating the overall presentation of the Consolidated Financial Statements and the Parent Company Financial Statements.
We believe that the audit evidence we have obtained is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for our audit opinion.
The audit has not resulted in any qualification.
column107:
Statutory Statement of Corporate Social Responsibility
1. Introduction
As an international Group, JYSK Holding A/S (âThe Groupâ) is in contact with thousands of customers, employees and business partners as well as other stakeholders every day. That requires commitment.
Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) is a continuous process where new areas and methods constantly develop. Our goal is always to be up to date with the development and, therefore, dialogue and cooperation with different stakeholders are very important. We consider the dialogue with our surroundings a part of the learning process and essential to obtaining a better understanding of the complex challenges we face as a global company.
The improvement of social and environmental conditions is an ongoing process, and we believe that cooperation, dialogue and commitment are the way to go. Due to the complexity of the CSR work, it is difficult to guarantee that we always choose the right solutions and business partners.
In these Financial Statements we report on five overall themes
Environment and climate
Supplier management
Partnerships
Customers
Employees
Management has assessed that the Group achieves a better effect from memberships of and commitment to the organisations BSCI, FSC, DIEH (JYSK A/S) and Save the Children rather than laying down our own human rights policy.
This report is the Companyâs report in accordance with sections 99(a) and 99(b) of the Danish Financial Statements Act.
2. Environment and climate
As a global Group, we work on minimising the negative environmental impact of the production of the products that we sell. We are therefore working on some specific initiatives such as replacement of lights, more sustainable wood in the production and optimisation of warehouse facilities for the purpose of reducing the negative environmental impact.
Sustainable wood
Wooden furniture represents a large part of our product range, and forest clearing and illegal wood trade are real threats to the environment in many regions. As a material part of JYSKâs product range includes wood, we have an obligation to ensure that the wood we use originates from a sustainable source. We therefore give priority to our efforts to increase the share of sustainable wood in our product range as we feel that we are able to make a difference in this area.
FSC
JYSK is a member of the FSCÂ®/â¢, which stands for Forest Stewardship Council. In an FSC-labelled forest, the number of trees cut down does not exceed the number of trees produced by the forest, and, consequently, consideration is shown to the local population and animal and plant lives in the forest in question. At the same time, the label ensures that the people working in FSC-certified forests are trained, receive the required safety gear and a decent pay.
All wooden garden furniture purchased for JYSKâs stores in the financial period is produced from FSC-certified wood, and 60% of our board-based furniture (measured in total number of items) purchased in the financial period was FSC-certified.
PEFC
It is not always possible to obtain FSC-certified wood for the production of goods for JYSK. Consequently, wood certified under other systems is also used such as PEFC-certified wood (Programme of the Endorsement of Forest Certification Schemes), which guarantees that the wood used originates from sustainable forestry like the FSC label. The PEFC label is found on several of JYSKâs indoor wood furniture ranges.
By requiring that our suppliers and business partners use FSC- and PEFC-certified wood in their production, we contribute to ensuring that our products come from sustainable areas. 20% of our board-based furniture (measured in total number of items) purchased in the financial period was PEFC-certified.
Our long-term target is for all products to be FSC-certified, which is a process we will continue in the financial period 2016/17.
Energy reduction and optimisation
By optimising and enhancing our energy efficiency, we will be able to reduce our total energy consumption and CO2 emission.
LED lighting
We are working on replacing all lighting in our stores by LED. LED bulbs are both cost- and energy-efficient and have a longer lifespan than ordinary lighting. The electricity savings of LED bulbs reach about 80% compared to traditional light sources. At JYSK, all new stores will be fitted with LED. This also applies when existing stores are relocated to other buildings.
JYSK has installed LED lighting in more than 50% of the stores and in more than 90% of the stores in Romania, the Czech Republic, Slovakia and Bulgaria. JYSKâs target is to install LED lighting in additionally 200 stores in the financial period 2016/17. The replacement is an ongoing process, and the long-term target is for all stores to be fitted with LED lighting.
Warehouse facilities
Throughout the past couple of years, we have focused on investing in new automated distribution centres, which means that, among other things, considerably less energy is used for heating as the automated distribution centres consist of high-bay stores which are only heated to five degrees centigrade.
During the financial period, The Group expanded its distribution centre in NÃ¤ssjÃ¶ in Sweden by 75,000 new pallet places in new unheated high-bay stores.
In continuation of this, the existing lighting in the distribution centres in Radomsko and NÃ¤ssjÃ¶ has been replaced by LED lighting in the same period.
Transport
Every day, we transport thousands of goods from the suppliers to the distribution centres and from the distribution centres to the stores. This requires much transport, which adds to our CO2 emission. We want to reduce this emission and have therefore taken a number of initiatives in this respect.
We are working on eg packing the goods more efficiently on the pallets before they are dispatched from the distribution centres to the stores. In this respect, we use e-learning to train our employee in packing the goods as efficiently as possible, and a number of technical tools are made available for the same purpose.
During the period, the distribution centre in Radomsko in Poland increased its m3 per loading metre by 5.5%. This means that there are 5.5% more m3 goods per loading metre in the lorries. Ultimately, this means that fewer lorries are driving from the warehouses to the stores, which saves CO2.
In connection with the expansion of the distribution centre in NÃ¤ssjÃ¶, new high-bay stores will be put into operation on a current basis, which will in the long term imply a reduction of transports from remote warehouses. The number of remote warehouses and the quantities stored there will be reduced during this period. The process will continue going forward, and the target for the financial period 2016/17 is that only one remote warehouse is used. This will ensure a considerable reduction of the total emission of CO2 in connection with transport between company warehouses.
During the next two years, JYSKâs Code of Conduct will be rolled out to all of JYSKâs carriers in connection with contract negotiations. This Code of Conduct will contribute to ensuring that the carriers meet JYSKâs requirements within human rights and the environment.
Waste handling
Goods are currently transported from our distribution centres to our stores. This generates a large amount of waste from packaging such as eg cardboard, plastic, wood and metal, a large part of which cannot be utilised optimally. Therefore, during the financial period 2015/16, initial initiatives have been taken in respect of a comprehensive project, the purpose of which is to improve waste handling in The Group.
The initiative involves all parts of The Group as well as the part of ApS af 19/12 2014 which relates to the operation of JYSK in Denmark, Holland and the UK. During the financial period, a total amount of approx EUR 2.5 million was spent on transport of used packaging and waste-related direct and indirect taxes. Our long-term target is to reduce this amount to nil over a three-year period. The first subsidiary goal of the process is to reduce the amount by EUR 500,000 in the financial period 2016/17. To JYSK this involves eg thorough sorting of the materials that are recyclable. It is moreover important to ensure that the materials are in good condition as it would affect both quality and the value of the recycle materials if they eg get wet.
By enhancing the efficiency of and optimising waste handling in the Company, we ensure that an increasing amount of waste is recycled rather than lost. Because of the initiative, there will also be fewer lorries on the roads transporting materials to and from distribution centres and stores. The initiative is therefore not only a mere cost-efficient solution, but is also a responsible and sustainable method for waste handling.
3. Supplier management
The Group has hundreds of suppliers globally. Teamwork with our suppliers is a fundamental element in our business, and this is thus an area where we can make the biggest difference with respect to eg the environment, human rights and animal welfare. At JYSK, we take responsibility, and we expect and demand that our suppliers do the same.
Business Social Compliance Initiative (BSCI)
Together with ApS 31/8 1984, The Group joined BSCI in 2006 as one of the first Danish companies. The Group and ApS 31/8 1984 share a joint membership as a large number of our suppliers are the same.
The BSCI is an international inspection and training system for suppliers. As members, companies agree to follow a shared Code of Conduct, which is a joint code containing 11 principles for running an ethical and socially responsible business. The principles are based on international conventions and, among other things, prohibit child labour, forced labour, corruption and discrimination, and set out requirements for safety, working hours and environmental protection.
Learn more about the 11 principles of the BSCI Code of Conduct (http://www.bsci-intl.org/content/bsci-code-conduct).
The 11 principles constitute the foundation of our Code of Conduct which JYSKâs suppliers must sign. By signing, JYSKâs suppliers commit to complying with the specific requirements and standards described. Through BSCI, we can check our suppliers and their production processes thus ensuring compliance with our Code of Conduct. We moreover offer our suppliers the opportunity to receive training in the 11 principles of the BSCI Code of Conduct and, not least, in the current issues faced in the countries in question.
It is important to us that our suppliers comply with our requirements. In this respect, we consider cooperation and involvement an important approach. Through involvement, we will contribute to influencing development in a positive direction. If we see a supplier making mistakes, our initial response will be to maintain the supplier and ensure that improvements are made rather than immediately terminate our cooperation. Therefore, we work systematically on improving the situation and processes in cooperation with our suppliers.
In the financial period, 639 audits were performed at the suppliers of The Group and ApS 31/8 1984, which corresponds to 60% of the total number of suppliers.
In the financial period, JYSK participated in BSCI training and in the BSCI Annual Conference in Brussels. Based on this training, JYSK has visited selected suppliers to ensure quality and compliance with BSCI, and has at the same time trained and sparred with suppliers on BSCI-related matters.
Animal welfare
A significant part of our business consists of sales of pillows and duvets filled with down and feathers from ducks and geese. We have 10 suppliers of down and feathers, and the fairly few suppliers compared to our large product range reflect our strong focus on ethics and quality.
We do not tolerate animal abuse of any kind. For the same reason, our suppliers bind themselves by contract to only supply down and feathers from slaughterhouses - ie from slaughtered fowl. Inspections, trade documents and supplier visits ensure that our suppliers do not purchase down and feathers plucked from live fowl.
The debate about down and feathers plucked from live fowl has been on the agenda several times during the past couple of years. Many people consider it more of a rule rather than an exception for down and feathers to be plucked from live fowl. However, according to the International Down and Feather Laboratory (IDFL) the reality is different as 99% of the down and feathers in the world are byproducts from the food industry and, therefore, originate from slaughtered fowl. Also, the process of plucking feathers from live fowl is substantially more expensive and, consequently, not profitable for the major part of companies.
Nevertheless, JYSK has chosen to constantly monitor our suppliers of down and feathers, and during the financial period, three audits were performed in cooperation with IDFL of the Chinese suppliers. One audit is effective for one year at a time, and, therefore, the audits will be performed again in the financial period 2016/17. The audits did not give rise to any suspicion of the suppliers delivering down and feathers from live fowl.
We also take a stand in respect of animal skins. We only sell skins from animals which are secondary byproducts from the food industry. The skins originate from slaughtered animals â ie animals which would be slaughtered anyway. The animals are therefore not slaughtered only for their skin. Tanning of skins is carried out without any harmful substances.
4. Partnerships
The surrounding world affects our company, just as our company has an impact on the surroundings. Therefore, JYSK wants dialogue and cooperation as they provide the best basis for fulfilling our responsibilities and meeting the challenges which we face as a global group.
Danish Ethical Trading Initiative (DIEH)
JYSK is a member of the DIEH. The DIEH is a Danish multi-stakeholder initiative for businesses, trade unions and popular organisations. The objective is to work jointly on ethical trade and find constructive solutions to the challenges faced by Danish enterprises in relation to suppliers in the developing countries and new growth economies.
During the financial period, JYSK has currently participated in meetings at the DIEH.
Save the Children
JYSK has been a business partner to Save the Children since 2008, and the Company was the main sponsor of Save the Children in Denmark in 2015.
The object of the sponsorship is to make a difference for the children and young people who are worst off in Denmark and in the world by giving them better access to education and development. Together with IDdesign and others, JYSK donated two million Danish kroner over a period of two years for the Save the Childrenâs work in Denmark and the rest of the world. The donations are spent on eg construction of temporary schools where children can take an education and find safety and definite bounds in an otherwise chaotic life. In Denmark the donations are spent on eg increased efforts to prevent bullying and establish a community of children where there is room for all.
FSC Denmark
JYSK is a member of and cooperates with FSC Denmark which, among other things, works for the positioning and dissemination of the FSC label in Denmark.
Danmarks Indsamling
Danmarks Indsamling is a national fund raising event in aid of the developing countries in Africa, Asia and Latin America arranged by the Danish Broadcasting Corporation and 12 of Denmarkâs largest humanitarian organisations.
In 2016, the theme for the fund raising was â10 years against povertyâ focusing on the poverty faced every day by some 800 million people in the world. Almost DKK 98 million was raised which is distributed to specific projects. JYSK supports the fund raising with a large sum each year.
The Danish Church Army
The Danish Church Army organisation operates warm shelters, hostels and group homes to help vulnerable people in Denmark who for some reason have endured hardships in life. Close to 10,000 people visits the organisationâs many places and they include people with psychiatric disorders, abusers, homeless people or people with criminal records. They may also be people who are lonely, which is a common phenomenon today. People are welcomed by the organisation if they need a place to sleep, need a shower or an inexpensive meal, or if they just need to talk.
As sponsor, JYSK donates every year sleeping bags, mattresses and socks to the Danish Church Army for the benefit of its visitors.
Disabled sports
At JYSK, we have chosen our main sponsorship to be awarded to disabled sports. The considerations behind our support of this type of sports are caused by the admirable commitment of the athletes. They prove that you can do whatever you want to do, and the partnership is based on joint values.
The sponsorship started after the Seoul 1988 Paralympics when the Danish para-athletes needed a main sponsor. This also makes the agreement between JYSK and the Danish para-sports confederation (DHIF) to one of the longest-ever sports sponsorships in Denmark. The sponsorship agreement involves eg fundraising lotteries in the Danish JYSK stores and support to local sports clubs.
In 2002, JYSK became the main sponsor of para-sports in Norway, and Sweden followed in 2004. In addition to that, JYSK is also sponsor for para-sports in Finland, the Czech Republic and Slovakia while JYSK Franchise supports in Canada, Iceland and on the Faroe Islands.
5. Customers
Consideration and thought for our customers and our surroundings is a cornerstones for us. Therefore, we naturally take responsibility for the products we sell.
Product safety and quality
Besides tests and documentation from suppliers, we also test the products ourselves. We moreover use external testing firms and spot-checking on a current basis. In the financial period, external testing firms have performed 360 tests and inspections on behalf of The Group.
JYSK has prepared an annual wheel that gives an overview of the various product groups, which helps ensuring that all product groups are tested within a given period.
JYSK has also prepared a model for quality checking which, among other things, comprises quality assurance, assembly days, quality check at reception at distribution centres and feedback from the stores.
In the financial period, we had âassembly daysâ when in the spring of 2016 a test team of JYSK employees travelled to China to assemble and test furniture for the 2016 indoor season. The furniture was subsequently checked again in Poland. The purpose of these âassembly daysâ was to ensure that the furniture which is subsequently sold in the stores meets our quality requirements. These procedures were also applied to our outdoor furniture.
JYSK made a video in the financial period describing our quality checking procedures.
Substances of very high concern (SVHC)
JYSK currently focuses on reducing the use of substances with suspicious effects. Therefore, as from 1 January 2017, we do not allow any SVHC in any of our products.
The Oeko-Tex label
The label ensures that the products are inspected for dangerous colouring agents and chemicals, and that the Oeko-Tex Standard 100 requirements have been met.
In the financial period, we have continued our work of extending the range of products which may be Oeko-Tex Standard 100 certified. The Oeko-Tex Standard 100 label is found on a large number of our products, among other things on 99% of our bed linen, sheets and towels. All textiles meet the requirements of the Oeko-Tex label.
The CertiPUR Label
The label is a voluntary standard to promote safety, health and environmental performance in flexible polyurethane foams used for, among other things, mattresses.
In the financial period, 35.7% of the mattresses and top mattresses sold by JYSK were labelled with the CertiPUR Label.
6. Employees
At The Group, we all have equal rights irrespective of gender, race, political affiliation and religious beliefs. In The Groupâ competence development, career paths and talent programmes, we present the possibilities offered by the Company to both genders.
Staff development
At The Group, we focus strongly on internal recruitment when filling executive positions. As a natural extension of this focus, we offer many opportunities for professional development and career.
With respect to increasing the representation of women at other executive levels, the Group did not give differential treatment to candidates because of their gender during the financial period.
As part of our internal career paths, JYSK works at all levels of the organisation under the performance management programme 'SIRIUS' to secure the internal pipeline. Under this programme, the performance of the individual employee is evaluated. The object of SIRIUS is to evaluate all employees - irrespective of their gender, race, political affiliation and religious beliefs - according to their ability to work under JYSKâs values which are JYSK VALUES and JYSK LEADERSHIP. Based on the work with SIRIUS, potential leaders are identified and selected for four development programmes at different levels.
In the external recruitment process, The Group wants to continuously ensure that all candidates have an equal opportunity to be considered for an executive position. This is ensured through training of the employees responsible for the recruitment.
Diversity
At JYSK, we want our employees to represent the demographic distribution in society, including the distribution of men and women in the individual countries. We find this to be a clear advantage for both our employees and our customers.
Generally, there is a balanced gender representation in the total staff.
It is, however, difficult to ensure a general balanced representation in all areas in the Company. At JYSK, we are of the opinion that during a recruitment process focus is first and foremost on qualifications - irrespective of the candidateâs gender. However, in areas where the difference is inappropriately large, it will be taken into account. In this case, it will be considered whether it would be beneficial to the employee group in question to increase the minority, be it by women or men. In general, the most important thing is, however, that we get the best candidate for the position.
At JYSK, the race, sexual orientation or religious beliefs of our employees are not important. Our clear conviction is that it does not affect an employeeâs ability to do his or her job.
JYSK is a family-owned company which is also reflected on the Board of Directors with its six board members. Our target ratio is that at least 25% of the board members are women. This target has been achieved as the Board of Directors is membered by four men and two women.
Job satisfaction
Employee satisfaction
At The Group, our employees and their views are important.
We therefore perform employee satisfaction surveys as they help us understand where to take measures to improve satisfaction and loyalty. In our 2016 survey 96% of all JYSKâs national and international employees responded. The higher the response rate, the more correct view we will get of the opinion of our employees. A high response rate is also often a sign of the employees being willing to express their views and of their confidence in being able to do so without facing any consequences. This is in line with JYSKâs values that dictate a right and duty to raise oneâs voice.
Our employees are asked to express their satisfaction and loyalty on a scale from 1 to 100 as shown below.
In respect of the employees in the stores, at the offices and the distribution centres, satisfaction reached an average rate of 78. Most employee groups expressed increasing satisfaction, especially at the distribution centres.
In this respect, attention should be called to particularly Romania with its average satisfaction rate of 88, China with its average rate of 85 and Bulgaria with its average rate of 83.
Loyalty reached an average rate of 79. In this respect, attention should be called to Romania with its average loyalty rate of 88, Serbia with its average rate of 84 and Poland with its average rate of 82.
In the areas where the satisfaction or loyalty rates are declining, we are making an effort to improve the feedback given by our employees. This applies to eg job content in respect of which our employees indicated that they faced high pressure in some periods on eg Black Friday and in the Holiday Season when they would like to have more support.
Safety
It is important that the employees have a safe and healthy working environment.
At the distribution centres in Radomsko and NÃ¤ssjÃ¶ 6 and 11 work-related accidents were registered in the financial period 2015/16 resulting in the involved employeeâs/employeesâ absence.
Overall, there is a target for the distribution centres to reduce the number of work-related accidents by 10% in the financial period 2016/17. This will be achieved eg through e-learning during the introductory period introducing the employee to the workplace and to safety at the distribution centre. The employees are trained in eg safe pallet handling and the way in which to pack the goods on the pallets to prevent them from tipping. JYSK also focuses on avoiding heavy lifts by investing in tools and new technology for both the distribution centres and the stores.
JYSK has moreover implemented processes to analyse work-related accidents at the distribution centres for the purpose of preventing future accidents from occurring. There is furthermore focus on changing the attitude to correct, safe behaviour at the workplace.
column108:
Managementâs Responsibility for the Consolidated Financial Statements and the Parent Company Financial Statements
Management is responsible for the preparation of Consolidated Financial Statements and Parent Company Financial Statements that give a true and fair view in accordance with the Danish Financial Statements Act, and for such internal control as Management determines is necessary to enable the preparation of Consolidated Financial Statements and Parent Company Financial Statements that are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error.
column109:
Statement on Managementâs Review
We have read Managementâs Review in accordance with the Danish Financial Statements Act. We have not performed any procedures additional to the audit of the Consolidated Financial Statements and the Parent Company Financial Statements. On this basis, in our opinion, the information provided in Managementâs Review is consistent with the Consolidated Financial Statements and the Parent Company Financial Statements.

column27: To the shareholders of JYSK Holding A/S
column30: The Annual Report was prepared in accordance with the Danish Financial Statements Act.
column31: In our opinion, the Parent Company Financial Statements and the Consolidated Financial Statements give a true and fair view of the financial position of the Parent Company and the Group at 31 August 2016 and of the results of the Parent Company and the Group operations and cash flows for 2015/16.
column34:
Cash Flow Statement
The cash flow statement shows the Groupâs cash flows for the year broken down by operating, investing and financing activities, changes for the year in cash and cash equivalents as well as the Groupâs cash and cash equivalents at the beginning and end of the year.
No cash flow statement has been prepared for the Parent Company as the Parent Company cash flows are included in the Consolidated Cash Flow Statement.
Cash flows from operating activities
Cash flows from operating activities are calculated as the net profit/loss for the year adjusted for changes in working capital and non-cash operating items such as depreciation, amortisation and impairment losses and provisions. Working capital comprises current assets less short-term debt excluding items included in cash and cash equivalents.
Cash flows from investing activities
Cash flows from investing activities comprise cash flows from acquisitions and disposals of intangible assets, tangible assets as well as fixed asset investments.
Cash flows from financing activities
Cash flows from financing activities comprise cash flows from the raising and repayment of long-term debt as well as payments to and from shareholders.

The cash flow statement cannot be immediately derived from the published financial records.
column35:
Derivative financial instruments
Derivative financial instruments are initially recognised in the balance sheet at cost and are subsequently remeasured at their fair values. Positive and negative fair values of derivative financial instruments are classified as âOther receivablesâ and âOther payablesâ, respectively.
Changes in fair values of derivative financial instruments are recognised in the income statement unless the derivative financial instrument is classified and qualify as a hedge.
column37:
The Financial Statements for 2015/16 are presented in TDKK.

Recognition and measurement
Revenues are recognised in the income statement as earned. Furthermore, value adjustments of financial assets and liabilities measured at fair value or amortised cost are recognised. Moreover, all expenses incurred to achieve the earnings for the year are recognised in the income statement, including depreciation, amortisation, impairment losses and provisions as well as reversals due to changed accounting estimates of amounts that have previously been recognised in the income statement.
Assets are recognised in the balance sheet when it is probable that future economic benefits attributable to the asset will flow to the Company, and the value of the asset can be measured reliably.
Liabilities are recognised in the balance sheet when it is probable that future economic benefits will flow out of the Company, and the value of the liability can be measured reliably.
Assets and liabilities are initially measured at cost. Subsequently, assets and liabilities are measured as described for each item below.
Certain financial assets and liabilities are measured at amortised cost, which involves the recognition of a constant effective interest rate over the maturity period. Amortised cost is calculated as original cost less any repayments and with addition/deduction of the cumulative amortisation of any difference between cost and the nominal amount. In this way, capital losses and gains are allocated over the maturity period.
Recognition and measurement take into account predictable losses and risks occurring before the presentation of the Annual Report which confirm or invalidate affairs and conditions existing at the balance sheet date.
column38:
Corporation tax receivables and liabilities
Current tax liabilities and receivables are recognised in the balance sheet as tax calculated on the taxable income for the year, adjusted for tax on the taxable income of previous years and for taxes paid on account. Extra payments and repayment under the on-account taxation scheme are recognised in financial income and expenses in the income statement.
column39:
Depreciation and amortisation
Depreciation and amortisation comprise depreciation and amortisation of tangible assets and intangible assets for the year.
column40:
Securities
Securities consist of listed bonds, which are measured at fair values at the balance sheet date. The fair value is stated on the basis of the most recently quoted selling price.
column41:
Prepayments.
Deferred income comprises payments received in respect of income in subsequent years.
column42:
Investments in subsidiaries and associates
Investments in subsidiaries and associates are recognised and measured under the equity method.
The items âInvestments in subsidiariesâ and âInvestments in associatesâ in the balance sheet include the proportionate ownership share of the net asset value of the enterprises calculated on the basis of the fair values of identifiable net assets at the date of acquisition with deduction or addition of unrealised intercompany profits or losses and with addition or deduction of any remaining value of positive or negative differences (goodwill or negative goodwill).
The total net revaluation of investments in subsidiaries and associates is transferred upon distribution of profit to âReserve for net revaluation under the equity methodâ under equity. The reserve is reduced by dividend distributed to the Parent Company and adjusted for other equity movements in subsidiaries and associates.

Investments in subsidiaries and associates
Subsidiaries and associates with a negative carrying amount are recognised at DKK 0. Any legal or constructive obligation of the Parent Company to cover the negative balance of the enterprise is recognised in provisions.
column43:
Cost of sales
Cost of sales comprises cost incurred in connection with the purchase of commercial products.
column44:
Staff expenses
Staff expenses comprise wages and salaries, including holiday pay and pensions as well as other social security costs etc. to the Company's employees. Allowances received from public authorities are deducted from staff expenses.
column45:
Equity - Dividend
Dividend distribution proposed by Management for the year is disclosed as a separate equity item.
column46:
Other external expenses
Other external expenses comprise sales and administrative expenses as well as expenses for premises.
column47:
Financial income and expenses
Financial income and expenses comprise interest, exchange adjustments, fees, etc.
column48:
Result from subsidiaries and associated companies
The items âResult from subsidiariesâ and âResult from associated companiesâ in the income statement include the proportionate share of the profit/loss for the year less goodwill amortisation.
column49:
Result from other investments
Results from other investments in the income statement include regulations on fair value and dividend paid.
column50:
Intangible assets
Software
Software is measured at the lower of cost less accumulated amortisation and the recoverable amount.
Software is amortised over 3 â 5 years.
Goodwill
Acquired goodwill is measured at cost less accumulated amortisation. Goodwill is amortised on a straight-line basis over the expected useful life which is estimated at 5 â 15 years.
column51:
Inventories
Inventories are measured at the lower of cost under the average cost formula and net realisable value. The net realisable value of inventories is calculated at the total of future sales revenue which the inventories are expected to generate at the balance sheet date in the process of normal operations allowing for marketability, obsolescence and development in expected selling price with deduction of selling expenses expected to be incurred to realise the sale.
The cost of goods for resale equals landed cost.
column52:
Other investments
Other investments are recognised and measured at fair value.

Deposits
Deposits are recognised and measured at cost.
column53:
Debts
Debts are measured at amortised cost, substantially corresponding to nominal value.
column54:
Other operating income and expenses
Other operating income and other operating expenses comprise items of a secondary nature to the activities of the enterprises, including gains and losses from the sale of intangible assets and tangible assets.
column55:
Tangible assets
Tangible assets are measured at cost with the addition of revaluations and less accumulated depreciation and impairment losses.
Cost comprises the cost of acquisition and expenses directly related to the acquisition up until the time when the asset is ready for use. In the case of assets of own construction, cost comprises direct and indirect expenses for labour, materials, components and sub-suppliers.
Interest expenses on loans raised directly for the financing of the production of tangible assets are recognised in cost over the period of production. All indirectly attributable borrowing costs are recognised in the income statement.
Depreciation based on cost with the addition of revaluations and reduced by any residual value is calculated on a straight-line basis over the expected useful lives of the assets, which are
Buildings25 years
Fixtures and fittings, tools and equipment4-5 years
Trucks and cars4-5 years
Leasehold improvementsRental period
Profit and losses from current replacement of tangible assets are recognised in âOther operating incomeâ or âOther operating expensesâ.
column56:
Provisions
Provisions are recognised when - in consequence of an event occurred before or on the balance sheet date - the Company has a legal or constructive obligation and it is probable that economic benefits must be given up to settle the obligation.
column57:
Receivables
Receivables are recognised in the balance sheet at the lower of amortised cost and net realisable value, which generally corresponds to nominal value less provisions for bad debts.
Provisions for bad debts are determined on the basis of an individual assessment of each receivable, and in respect of trade receivables, a general provision is also made based on the Companyâs experience from previous years.

Prepayments
Prepayments comprise prepaid expenses concerning rent, insurance premiums, subscriptions and interest.
column58:
Revenue
Revenue from the sale of goods for resale is recognised in the income statement when the sale is considered effected based on the following criteria
delivery has been made before year end;
a binding sales agreement has been made;
the sales price has been determined; and
payment has been received or may with reasonable certainty be expected to be received.
Revenue is recognised exclusive of VAT and net of discounts relating to sales.
column59:
Tax on profit for the year
Tax for the year consists of current tax for the year and any changes in deferred tax for the year. The tax attributable to the profit for the year is recognised in the income statement, whereas the tax attributable to equity transactions is recognised directly in equity.
Any changes in deferred tax due to changes to tax rates are recognised in the income statement.
The Company is jointly taxed with its subsidiaries. The tax effect of the joint taxation with group enterprises is allocated to enterprises showing profits or losses in proportion to their taxable incomes. The jointly taxed enterprises have adopted the on-account taxation scheme.
column60:
Deferred tax assets and liabilities
Deferred tax is recognised in respect of all temporary differences between the carrying amount and the tax base of assets and liabilities. Deferred tax on temporary differences concerning non-taxable amortisable goodwill as well as other items is not recognised where, unless arising from acquisitions, they have arisen at the date of acquisition without affecting the profit/loss for the year or the taxable income.
Deferred tax is measured on the basis of the tax rules and tax rates that will be effective under the legislation at the balance sheet date when the deferred tax is expected to crystallise as current tax. In cases where the computation of the tax base may be made according to alternative tax rules, deferred tax is measured on the basis of the intended use of the asset and settlement of the liability, respectively.
Deferred tax assets, including the tax base of tax loss carry-forwards, are measured at the value at which the asset is expected to be realised, either by elimination in tax on future earnings or by set-off against deferred tax liabilities.
Deferred tax assets and liabilities are offset within the same legal tax entity.
column61:
Financial Highlights
Ratios are calculated as follows
Return on assets = Profit before financials x 100/Total assets
Solvency ratio = Equity at year end x 100/Total assets
Return on equity = Net profit for the year x 100/Average equity
column62:
Translation policies
Transactions in foreign currencies are translated during the year at the exchange rates at the dates of transaction. Exchange gains and losses arising due to differences between the transaction date rates and the rates at the dates of payment are recognised in financial income and expenses in the income statement.
Receivables, payables and other monetary items in foreign currencies that have not been settled at the balance sheet date are translated at the exchange rates at the balance sheet date. Any differences between the exchange rates at the balance sheet date and the transaction date rates are recognised in financial income and expenses in the income statement.
The income statements of foreign subsidiaries and associates that are separate legal entities are translated at the exchange rates at the dates of transaction or an approximated average exchange rate. Balance sheet line items are translated at the exchange rates at the balance sheet dates. Exchange adjustments arising on the translation of the opening equity and exchange adjustments arising from the translation of the income statements at the balance sheet dates are recognised directly in equity.
